sec.ex.title: Example of information matrix
sec.ex.text1: Let $X_1,\dots,X_n$ be i.i.d. random variables with p.d.f. $\sigma^{-1} f(\sigma^{-1}(x-\mu))$, and let $\theta = (\mu,\sigma)$. Then the Fisher information matrix is:
sec.ex.eq1: $$I(\theta) = \frac{n}{\sigma^2}\begin{pmatrix} \int \frac{[f'(x)]^2}{f(x)}dx & \int \frac{f'(x)[x f'(x) + f(x)]}{f(x)}dx \\ \int \frac{f'(x)[x f'(x) + f(x)]}{f(x)}dx & \int \frac{[x f'(x) + f(x)]^2}{f(x)}dx \end{pmatrix}.$$
sec.exp.title: Exponential family and efficiency
sec.exp.text1: An estimator $T(X)$ is efficient if it achieves the Cramér–Rao lower bound. The equality holds in the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality when $T(X)$ and $\frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}\log f_\theta(X)$ are linearly related. That is,
sec.exp.eq3: $$\therefore f_\theta(x) \text{ belongs to an exponential family, and } T(X) \text{ is sufficient.}$$
